DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Changed from chlorine gas to 12.5% bleach

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Cunningham-East Montgomery Water Treatment Plant (CEMWTP) Risk Management Plan consist of the
Cunningham-East Montgomery W.T.P. employees working together to insure that all applicable procedures of the
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Prevention Program are adhered to.

     CEMWTP uses chlorine to disinfect the water treated at this facility. CEMWTP has a chlorine storage room on
the southwest corner of the building. This room houses the chlorine storage equipment, leak detection equipment and
the manifold that the chlorine cylinders are mounted to. The amount of chlorine handled is four, one ton containers.
The chlorine storage room is usually checked each shift. In addition to the storage room on the first floor, there is a
chlorine feed room on the second floor. The room on the second floor consists of chlorine feed equipment as well as 
chlorine leak detection equipment. CEMWTP operators respond to any alarms that may occur.

     The Offsite Consequence analysis includes consideration of two chlorine release scenarios, identified as "worst
case release" and "alternative scenario". The first scenario as defined by EPA, which states that "the owner or
operator shall assume that the ? maximum quantity in the largest vessel ? is released as a gas over 10 minutes",
due to an uspecified failure. The alternative scenario is defined as "more likely to occur that the worst-case release
scenario".

     The worst-case release scenario at Cunningham-East Montgomery W.T.P. involves failure of a one ton container.
The model used for this scenario is RMP* Comp Ver. 1.05 with the results as follows? Chemical: Chlorine, CAS#
7782-50-5
Category: Toxic Gas
Scenario: Worst-case
Liquefied Under pressure
Quantity Released: 1 ton
Release Duration: 10 min.
Release Rate: 110 pounds per min.
Mitigation Measures: Released in enclosed space, in direct contact with outside air.
Topography: Rural surroundings (terrain generally flat and unobstructed)
Toxic Endpoint: 0.

0087 mg/l; basis:EPRG-2
Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint: 2.2 miles
Number of People Affected: 100
Assumptions About This Scenario?
Wind Speed: 1.5 Meters/second (3.4 miles/hour)
Stability Class: F
Air Temperature: 77 degrees F (25 degrees C)

     The alternative release scenario involves a 1/2 inch hole 15 inches below the top level of the liquid in a 1 ton
cylinder. Again the model used was RMP* Comp Ver. 1.05 with the results as follows?
Chemical: Chlorine, CAS#: 7782-50-5
Category: Toxic Gas
Scenario: Alternative
Liquefied under pressure
Release Duration: 8 min.
Storage Parameters: Hole in liquid space of tank
Height of Liquid Column Above Hole: 15 inches
Release Rate: 200 pounds per minute
Mitigation Measures: Released in enclosed space, in direct contact with outside air.
Topography: Rural surroundings (terrain generally flat and unobstructed)
Toxic Endpoint: 0.0087 mg/l; basis:EPRG-2
Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint: 1.2 miles
Number of People Affected: 50
Assumptions About This Scenario?
Wind Speed: 3 Meters/second (6.7 miles/hour)
Stability Class: D
Air Temperature: 77 degrees F (25 degrees C)

     The CEMWTP accidental release program is based on the following key elements:
(1) Performance of a hazard review of equipment and procedures
(2) High level of training of the operators
(3) Preventive maintenance program
(4) Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of other employees
(5) Weekly inspections of leak detection equipment
(6) An ongoing inspection and auditing program

     There has been no accidental release of chlorine in the past five years at CEMWTP.

     The emergency response plan at this facility includes coordination with the Montgomery County Government
Emergency Management Agency as well as the U.S. Coast Guard. The emergency response plan includes
emergency shutdown procedure, evacuation plan, and emergency personnel notification. CEMWTP safety
